title: Business lobby offers union olive branch
text:
The business lobby has offered to work more closely with unions on key issues, but insists new laws to crack down on misconduct must be backed to repair the industrial movement's reputation.

Business Council chief Jennifer Westacott spoke at a forum at Melbourne's La Trobe University alongside former union boss Bill Kelty on Wednesday night.

Ms Westacott admitted she had been a union member up until she left the public service and believed they are "fundamental to the wellbeing of our society".

But she was concerned the traditional positive role of unions was "diminishing", mainly because of their focus on "campaigning and regime change" instead of the long-term interest of the nation.

She condemned the "ideological obstructionism" seen in unions rejecting free trade agreements, skilled migration and over-stating the casualisation of the workforce.

Unions were at their worst when they saw "a culture of bullying and intimidation as a badge of honour", she said.

"It is not - it is shameful cowardice, it is a turn off to the community, it unleashes the anti-union fetishists and it cripples the enterprise agreement system which has at its core the principle of good faith bargaining," she said.

"This is why we need the government's integrity bills to pass the Senate."

However, in a bid to find common ground with unions, Ms Westacott said the industrial movement and business needed to join forces to address productivity and wage decline.

This should involve fixing the skills system and making enterprise bargaining work better.

"Tonight, I call again for a meeting between employers and the union movement to sit down and save the enterprise bargaining system," she said.

"This is the system that was born out of the era of consensus and drove higher productivity and wage growth for decades."

Entrenched disadvantage and the plight of low-paid workers should also be addressed.
